titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Donald Grant Mitchell Papers
titlestmt.author: by Michael Rush and Aubrey Novak

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:44

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Donald Grant Mitchell papers contain original correspondence and manuscripts by the prominent nineteenth-century New Haven-area author. Correspondents include Henry Ward Beecher, Henry Augustin Beers, George Washington Cable, William Maxwell Evarts, Fitz-Greene Halleck, Oliver Wendell Holmes, Thomas Raynesford Lounsbury, Hamilton Wright Mabie, Noah Porter, Theodore Roosevelt, Charles Scribner, Edmund Clarence Stedman, Harriet Beecher Stowe, and others. Writings include drafts for published and unpublished work and journals, including substantive drafts for Fresh Gleanings (1847), American Lands and Letters (1897-1899), English Lands, Letters and Kings (1889-1890), and Wet Days at Edgewood (1865), as well as an unpublished "History of Venice." Other materials include biographical and bibliographical material, financial and legal records, photographs, and printed ephemera.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired through various gifts and purchases from 1938 to 1974. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Donald Grant Mitchell Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Donald Grant Mitchell Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection received preliminary processing at an unknown date. During further processing in 2011, the material was listed below in the order in which it was arranged and described in the card catalog (Za Mitchell 1, Za Mitchell 2, etc.), with broad groupings for correspondence, writings, and other papers.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Donald Grant Mitchell Papers (MSS #140). New Haven Museum, New Haven, Connecticut.

bioghist.head: Donald Grant Mitchell (1822-1908)
bioghist.p: Donald Grant Mitchell, essayist and novelist, was born in Norwich, Connecticut, graduated from Yale College in 1841 and, after serving abroad briefly as U.S. consul in Venice, Italy, from 1853 to 1854, settled near New Haven, Connecticut. Mitchell wrote literary criticism, travel literature, and volumes of essays on rural themes, including Reveries of a Bachelor (1850), My Farm of Edgewood: A Country Book (1863), and Rural Studies (1867). Other works include the novel Doctor Johns (1866), About Old Story Tellers (1878), and American Lands and Letters (1897â€“1899).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Donald Grant Mitchell papers contain original correspondence and manuscripts by the prominent nineteenth-century New Haven area author. Correspondents include Henry Ward Beecher, Henry Augustin Beers, George Washington Cable, William Maxwell Evarts, Fitz-Greene Halleck, Oliver Wendell Holmes, Thomas Raynesford Lounsbury, Hamilton Wright Mabie, Noah Porter, Theodore Roosevelt, Charles Scribner, Edmund Clarence Stedman, Harriet Beecher Stowe, and others. Writings include drafts for published and unpublished work and journals, including substantive drafts for Fresh Gleanings (1847), American Lands and Letters (1897-1899), English Lands, Letters and Kings (1889-1890), and Wet Days at Edgewood (1865), as well as an unpublished "History of Venice." Other materials include biographical and bibliographical material, financial and legal records, photographs, and printed ephemera.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged according to Za Mitchell numbers in card catalog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains letters from Mitchell to others, including William Williams, Charles Scribner, and Mary (Perkins) Goddard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes letters to Walter L. Mitchell

scopecontent.p: Originally the day book of attorney Levi H. Goddard, including financial records and clippings of Mitchell's Letters from Paris (1848) and Capitol Sketches

unittitle.title: The Dignity of Learning: A Valedictory Oration

did.unittitle: "J. G. Dill's Best Cut Plug" tobacco tin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains Mitchell's Skull and Bones pin, undated, and an award medal granted to Mitchell by the New York State Agriculture Society, 1843.
